repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Fifth Palestinian
            National Development Plan Policy Grant Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors discussed the
            request for replenishment of the trust fund for Gaza and
            West Bank and recommended that the Board of Governors
            authorize a transfer from International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) surplus of the amount
            of United States (US) 55 million dollars to the trust fund.
            Directors also approved the Fifth Palestinian National
            Development Plan Policy Grant for West Bank and Gaza to the
            Palestinian Liberation Organization for the benefit of the
            Palestinian Authority (PA) in the amount of US 40 million
            dollars on the terms and conditions set out in the
            President's memorandum. Directors noted that the World
            Bank's trust fund support has a catalytic and
            leveraging effect among donors who provide essential support
            for the economy. Directors noted that the establishment of a
            World Bank-administered trust fund in 2012 to provide debt
            relief to West Bank and Gaza was an important, albeit
            temporary, measure to relieve fiscal stress. They encouraged
            innovative approaches by International Finance Corporation
            (IFC) and Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) to
            stimulate private investment and encouraged the authority to
            continue reforms that support private sector growth.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Fourth Support
            Palestinian National Development Plan Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fourth Support
            Palestinian National Development Plan Program Project for
            West Bank and Gaza were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            program design needs to be realistic, taking into account
            the political economy, the context of fragility, technical
            and other relevant challenges and risks. Specifically the
            technical challenges of implementing specific reforms ought
            to be taken into account in operation design. The reform
            aimed at introducing a payroll system in two ministries on
            pilot basis was not implemented as intended. This was
            evidently not due to inadequate ownership on the
            government's side, but rather because of the technical
            challenge of implementing the reform within a given
            timeframe turned insurmountable. Future operations should
            assess not only the readiness to implement particular
            reforms, but also the technical feasibility, when proposed
            reforms have to undergo an implementation process that may
            be technically challenging. Single tranche operations can
            and should be designed with a medium-term agenda in mind
            whenever possible. While it will probably not be appropriate
            to design a programmatic DPG, given the high level of
            uncertainty in West Bank and Gaza, this operation was
            designed with some medium term objectives in mind and has
            been successfully used as a platform to support the dialogue
            with the authorities on the medium term program, even when
            the implementation of some of its actions had to be
            postponed. Finally, the medium term outlook has been a
            useful tool in the preparation of a follow up operation.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Fourth Support
            Palestinian National Development Plan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Fourth
            Support Palestinian National Development Plan Program for
            West Bank and Gaza is to help the Palestinian Authority (PA)
            to implement the new National Development Plan which will
            specifically support efforts to improve the fiscal position
            and increase government transparency and accountability.
            This document is the fourth Development Policy Grant (DPG)
            to the PA in support of the new National Development Plan
            2011-2013. After a successful episode of implementing the
            Palestinian Recovery and Development Plan (PRDP 2008-2010),
            the caretaker government put forward the new National
            Development Plan (NDP 2011-2013). Under the earlier PRDP
            2008-2010, the caretaker government set out towards
            restoring the basic operating systems of the PA while
            reforming and creating stronger public institutions that
            will form the basis of a future Palestinian state. The
            current NDP 2011-2013 aims to move the PA fiscal and
            institutional performance beyond recovery and towards
            sustainability, by gradually reducing dependence on foreign
            assistance while continuing to improve the welfare of
            citizens. In February 2011 the PA cabinet resigned with the
            expectation of formation of a new cabinet within five weeks.
            This did not happen and the existing cabinet has continued
            in an acting capacity. On May 4, 2011, the PA in the West
            Bank signed a reconciliation agreement with the leadership
            in Gaza, calling for the formation of an interim unity
            government and announcing a plan to hold national elections
            by 2012.
